item.title: The blitz: rare colour photographs
item.trailText: As the 75th anniversary of the blitz – Germany’s sustained bombing campaign of the UK in the second world war – approaches, these beautiful and striking pictures show the famous bombsites, the tin helmets, the victory rolls and the carry-on spirit
item.standFirst:
As the 75th anniversary of the blitz – Germany’s sustained bombing campaign of the UK in the second world war – approaches, these beautiful and striking pictures show the famous bombsites, the tin helmets, the victory rolls and the carry-on spirit

  • Blitzed Brits is at IWM North, Manchester, from 11 July to 10 April 2016

cards.title: The Guardian film show / Reviews of Ted 2, Dear White People, Love and Mercy, The Human Centipede 3
cards.rawTitle: Reviews of Ted 2, Dear White People, Love and Mercy, The Human Centipede 3

item.title: The Guardian film show: Ted 2, Dear White People, Love and Mercy, The Human Centipede 3
item.trailText: In this week's show, our critics review a comedy sequel, the end of a horror franchise, plus a race relations satire and a biopic of Brian Wilson
item.standFirst:
In this week's show, Xan Brooks, Peter Bradshaw and Henry Barnes review Paul Dano and John Cusack as Brian Wilson in Love and Mercy; the return of Seth MacFarlane's foul-mouthed teddy bear in Ted 2; Justin Simien's race satire Dear White People and the final instalment in the Human Centipede horror series. Plus, the team answer your questions, which you can paste in the comments below

• Don't fancy watching the full show? Here's standalone reviews of Ted 2, Love and Mercy, Dear White People and The Human Centipede 3
item.byline: Xan Brooks, Peter Bradshaw, Henry Barnes and Zoran Trajkovic

cards.title: Tunisia attack / Gunman Seifeddine Rezgui on beach with Kalashnikov
cards.rawTitle: Gunman Seifeddine Rezgui on beach with Kalashnikov

item.title: Tunisia gunman Seifeddine Rezgui on beach with Kalashnikov – new video footage
item.trailText: Chilling new footage has emerged of Tunisian gunman Seifeddine Rezgui walking along the beach with a Kalashnikov assault rifle
item.standFirst: Chilling new footage of Tunisian gunman Seifeddine Rezgui walking along the beach with a Kalashnikov assault rifle. The footage, published by the Czech Republic news website iDNES.cz, shows a close-up view of the man who went onto kill 38 tourists, including 30 Britons, in Sousse on 26 June

cards.title: Photo highlights / Electric planes and pop pensioners

item.title: Photo highlights of the day: electric planes and pop pensioners
item.trailText: The Guardian’s picture editors bring you a selection of the best photographs from around the world, including an electric cross-Channel flight, a Japanese ‘girl band’ and the Pamplona bull run
item.standFirst: The Guardian’s picture editors bring you a selection of the best photographs from around the world, including an electric cross-Channel flight, a Japanese ‘girl band’ and the Pamplona bull run

displayImages.caption: Calais, France Pilot Didier Estyene celebrates after landing the Airbus E-Fan electric-powered plane in Calais, France, following his successful crossing of the Channel from Lydd airport in Kent Photograph: Gareth Fuller/PA
displayImages.altText: Pilot Didier Estyene celebrates after landing the Airbus E-Fan electric-powered plane in Calais, France, following his successful crossing of the Channel from Lydd airport in Kent
displayImages.cleanCaption: Calais, France Pilot Didier Estyene celebrates after landing the Airbus E-Fan electric-powered plane in Calais, France, following his successful crossing of the Channel from Lydd airport in Kent

displayImages.caption: Santa Cruz, Bolivia Nuns sing and dance as they wait for Pope Francis at a meeting with Catholic priests in the Don Bosco school Photograph: Mariana Bazo/Reuters
displayImages.altText: Nuns sing and dance as they wait for Pope Francis at a meeting with Catholic priests and nuns in the Don Bosco school in Santa Cruz, Bolivia
displayImages.cleanCaption: Santa Cruz, Bolivia Nuns sing and dance as they wait for Pope Francis at a meeting with Catholic priests in the Don Bosco school

displayImages.caption: Konama Island, Japan A troupe of singers and dancers from Kohama Island wearing traditional local costumes perform at a herb garden. They joke about knocking on heaven’s door, but a Japanese ‘girl band’ with an average age of 84 have inspired grandmothers everywhere by becoming pop idols Photograph: Toru Yamanaka/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: A troupe of singers and dancers from Kohama Island wearing traditional local costumes perform at a herb garden. They joke about knocking on heaven’s door, but a Japanese ‘girl band’ with an average age of 84 have inspired grandmothers everywhere by becoming pop idols
displayImages.cleanCaption: Konama Island, Japan A troupe of singers and dancers from Kohama Island wearing traditional local costumes perform at a herb garden. They joke about knocking on heaven’s door, but a Japanese ‘girl band’ with an average age of 84 have inspired grandmothers everywhere by becoming pop idols

displayImages.caption: London, England Members of the RAF gather outside Buckingham Palace for a flypast to mark the 75th anniversary of the Battle of Britain Photograph: Stefan Rousseau/PA
displayImages.altText: Members of the RAF gather outside Buckingham Palace in London for a flypast to mark the 75th anniversary of the Battle of Britain
displayImages.cleanCaption: London, England Members of the RAF gather outside Buckingham Palace for a flypast to mark the 75th anniversary of the Battle of Britain

displayImages.caption: Pamplona, Spain Revellers run as bulls are released on the fourth day of the 2015 Running of the Bulls festival Photograph: Mikel Cia Da Riva/Demotix/Corbis
displayImages.altText: Revellers run as bulls are released on the fourth day of the 2015 Running of the Bulls festival in Pamplona, Spain
displayImages.cleanCaption: Pamplona, Spain Revellers run as bulls are released on the fourth day of the 2015 Running of the Bulls festival

displayImages.caption: Frankfurt am Main, Germany A blurred panorama of Römerberg historic centre is reflected in a soap bubble Photograph: Frank Rumpenhorst/EPA
displayImages.altText: A blurred panorama of Roemerberg historic centre is reflected in a soap bubble in Frankfurt am Main, Germany
displayImages.cleanCaption: Frankfurt am Main, Germany A blurred panorama of Römerberg historic centre is reflected in a soap bubble

displayImages.caption: Gevgelija, Macedonia Migrants walk on train tracks towards the town on the Macedonia-Greece border, trying to catch a train to Serbia and the north European countries. Amnesty International has accused Balkan countries of mistreating migrants passing through their territories on the way to the European Union, saying people fleeing war were being ‘shamefully let down’ Photograph: Robert Atanasovski/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Migrants walk on train tracks towards Gevgelija on the Macedonia-Greece border, trying to catch a train to Serbia and the north European countries
displayImages.cleanCaption: Gevgelija, Macedonia Migrants walk on train tracks towards the town on the Macedonia-Greece border, trying to catch a train to Serbia and the north European countries. Amnesty International has accused Balkan countries of mistreating migrants passing through their territories on the way to the European Union, saying people fleeing war were being ‘shamefully let down’

displayImages.caption: Toronto, Canada Members of Argentina’s synchronised swimming team perform during the technical routine competition for the Pan Am Games Photograph: Gregory Bull/AP
displayImages.altText: Members of Argentina’s synchronised swimming team perform during the technical routine competition for the Pan Am Games in Toronto, Canada
displayImages.cleanCaption: Toronto, Canada Members of Argentina’s synchronised swimming team perform during the technical routine competition for the Pan Am Games

displayImages.caption: Tokyo, Japan A woman looks at goldfish through the warped wall of a fishtank at the Art Aquarium exhibition. Several thousand goldfish are displayed in dozens of uniquely shaped tanks, using LEDs, projection mapping and music in a show that was produced by Japanese designer Hidetomo Kimura Photograph: Thomas Peter/Reuters
displayImages.altText: A woman looks at goldfish through the warped wall of a fishtank at the Art Aquarium exhibition in Tokyo, Japan
displayImages.cleanCaption: Tokyo, Japan A woman looks at goldfish through the warped wall of a fishtank at the Art Aquarium exhibition. Several thousand goldfish are displayed in dozens of uniquely shaped tanks, using LEDs, projection mapping and music in a show that was produced by Japanese designer Hidetomo Kimura

displayImages.caption: Buenos Aires, Argentina A bichon frise takes part in the International Dog Show Photograph: Martin Zabala/Xinhua/Corbis
displayImages.altText: A bichon frise takes part in the International Dog Show in Buenos Aires, Argentina
displayImages.cleanCaption: Buenos Aires, Argentina A bichon frise takes part in the International Dog Show

displayImages.caption: Columbia, South Carolina, US The South Carolina governor, Nikki Haley, is applauded after signing a bill to remove the Confederate flag from the state house grounds. Debate on the flag was reignited three weeks ago after the mass murder at Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal church Photograph: Sean Rayford/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: The South Carolina governor, Nikki Haley, is applauded after signing a bill to remove the Confederate flag from the state house grounds
displayImages.cleanCaption: Columbia, South Carolina, US The South Carolina governor, Nikki Haley, is applauded after signing a bill to remove the Confederate flag from the state house grounds. Debate on the flag was reignited three weeks ago after the mass murder at Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal church

displayImages.caption: Xiapu, China People dodge waves in Sansha township in south-east China’s Fujian province. China is on highest alert as super typhoon Chan-Hom approaches the eastern coast at high speeds Photograph: Xinhua/Rex Shutterstock
displayImages.altText: People dodge waves in Sansha township in south-east China’s Fujian province. China is on highest alert as super typhoon Chan-Hom approaches the eastern coast at high speeds
displayImages.cleanCaption: Xiapu, China People dodge waves in Sansha township in south-east China’s Fujian province. China is on highest alert as super typhoon Chan-Hom approaches the eastern coast at high speeds

displayImages.cleanCaption: Friedrichskoog, Germany A young seal, named Thies, waits in the seal station for its re-introduction into the wild

displayImages.caption: Suphan Buri, Thailand A farmer walks in her dry rice field. In Thailand’s central province of Suphan Buri farmers are becoming increasingly desperate for water to irrigate their parched fields as the rice-producing nation suffers its worst drought in more than a decade Photograph: Chaiwat Subprasom/Reuters
displayImages.altText: A farmer walks in her dry rice field in Suphan Buri, Thailand. In Thailand’s central province of Suphan Buri farmers are becoming increasingly desperate for water to irrigate their parched fields as the rice-producing nation suffers its worst drought in more than a decade.

Several thousand goldfish are displayed in dozens of uniquely shaped tanks, using LEDs, projection mapping and music in a show that was produced by Japanese designer Hidetomo Kimura

image.caption: Columbia, South Carolina, US The South Carolina governor, Nikki Haley, is applauded after signing a bill to remove the Confederate flag from the state house grounds. In Thailand’s central province of Suphan Buri farmers are becoming increasingly desperate for water to irrigate their parched fields as the rice-producing nation suffers its worst drought in more than a decade Photograph: Chaiwat Subprasom/Reuters

cards.title: That’s me in the picture / Bruce McCandless, 47, in the world’s first untethered space flight, February 1984
cards.rawTitle: Bruce McCandless, 47, in the world’s first untethered space flight, February 1984

item.title: That’s me in the picture: Bruce McCandless, 47, in the world’s first untethered space flight, February 1984
item.trailText: ‘I wanted to say something similar to Neil [Armstrong] when he landed on the moon, so I said, “It may have been a small step for Neil, but it’s a heck of a big leap for me.” That loosened the tension a bit’
item.standFirst: ‘I wanted to say something similar to Neil [Armstrong] when he landed on the moon, so I said, “It may have been a small step for Neil, but it’s a heck of a big leap for me.” That loosened the tension a bit’
item.body:
The main aim of our nine-day mission on Challenger was the release and deployment of two communications satellites; the walk would follow that. It was a long time in the making: decades earlier, I helped develop the jet-propelled backpack I’m wearing, an MMU, or Manned Manoeuvring Unit. We were still testing and tweaking it six weeks before we went up. I was delighted to have been picked for the mission: it was a murky selection process, lots of back and forth between mission command and management.

The day before my walk, we reduced the pressure and increased the oxygen in the shuttle to get the nitrogen out of my bloodstream, otherwise I’d get the bends. Where I live now, outside Denver at an altitude of 8,300ft, has lower oxygen levels than the cabin did that day.

On the day itself, I put on my underwear, complete with airducts and flexible tubing filled with water to cool me down, and my pressure suit. The crew said, “You’re ready. Go, go, go!” so I stepped into the airlock, closed the hatch, depressurised it, opened it – and away I went.

I don’t like those overused lines “slipped the surly bonds of Earth”, but when I was free from the shuttle, they felt accurate. It was a wonderful feeling, a mix of personal elation and professional pride: it had taken many years to get to that point. Several people were sceptical it would work, and with 300 hours of flying practice, I was over-trained. My wife was at mission control, and there was quite a bit of apprehension. I wanted to say something similar to Neil [Armstrong] when he landed on the moon, so I said, “It may have been a small step for Neil, but it’s a heck of a big leap for me.” That loosened the tension a bit.

I’d been told of the quiet vacuum you experience in space, but with three radio links saying, “How’s your oxygen holding out?” “Stay away from the engines!” “When’s my turn?” it wasn’t that peaceful.

My walk lasted six hours 45 minutes, and I stayed alongside the shuttle the whole time, moving 100 yards one way, 100 yards back. I was travelling at more than 18,000 miles an hour, but wasn’t aware of it, because the shuttle was going at the same speed. It was only when I looked at the Earth that I could tell we were moving fairly rapidly. At one point, I noticed we were over the Florida peninsula: it was reassuring to see something I recognised.

An untethered space walk like this would be unlikely today, with the shuttle programme wound up, though Nasa is now working on an advanced version of the MMU for the exploration of asteroids. You can’t walk on them – there’s nothing to hold on to, they’re like big lumpy potatoes – but what you can do is fly around them, push up against them.

This photograph, taken by Robert Gibson from the shuttle, is beautiful, partly because the sun is shining directly on me. That’s why I have my visor down (although if you look closely, you can make out a few of my features). It’s also one of its attractions: my anonymity means people can imagine themselves doing the same thing. At visitor centres, they often have life-sized cardboard versions with the visor cut out, so people can peep through. Like Neil said in 1969, I was representing mankind up there.

• Interview by Hannah Booth

Are you in a famous photograph? Email thatsme@theguardian.com
